metadata.title: Texas Solar Utility Buyback Rates Database
metadata.notes: Texas has a deregulated ERCOT market. T&D utilities handle wires/meters, REPs set retail/buyback rates. Municipal utilities and co-ops are vertically integrated and set their own rates. As of 2026, true 1:1 net metering is rare in Texas. Most REPs offer fixed-credit or real-time wholesale buyback plans. Residential ITC ended Jan 1 2026, making TPO (lease/PPA) dominant for new installs.

market_context.regulatory_framework: Texas has no statewide net metering mandate. Each REP and municipal utility sets its own buyback terms.
market_context.ercot_deregulated_areas: Most of Texas excluding El Paso, parts of East Texas (Entergy), and municipal/co-op territories

2026_trends.fixed_export_rates: Most REPs offer 3-5 cents/kWh fixed export credits
2026_trends.real_time_plans: Growing trend toward real-time wholesale pricing that can spike during peak summer hours
2026_trends.battery_incentives: Increasing focus on battery+solar plans with higher buyback rates during peak demand
2026_trends.itc_change: Residential ITC expired Jan 1 2026; TPO (lease/PPA) now dominant as commercial ITC still available through TPO

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: 9.91 cents/kWh credit for 100% of solar production
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Separate production meter; all solar production credited at VoS rate regardless of consumption timing
solar_program.credit_rollover: Month-to-month as bill credits; non-transferable; no cash-out
solar_program.system_size_notes: Residential VoS limited to 20 kW; commercial systems 50 kW - 10 MW eligible for Solar Standard Offer Program

interconnection.process: Submit application through Austin Energy; requires one-line diagram, site plan, equipment specs
interconnection.fees: Customer responsible for all interconnection costs
interconnection.meter: Separate production meter installed by Austin Energy

rebates.residential: Check current availability - historically offered rebates but funding varies
rebates.commercial: Solar Standard Offer Program for systems 50 kW - 10 MW

municipal_utilities.name: CPS Energy
municipal_utilities.service_territory: San Antonio, TX metro area (Bexar County and surrounding)

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: Full retail credit for generation up to monthly consumption; excess above consumption credited at avoided cost: ~2.0 cents/kWh summer (Jun-Sep), ~1.65 cents/kWh non-summer (Oct-May)
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Net billing - generation offsets consumption at retail rate, excess at avoided cost
solar_program.credit_rollover: Dollar credits roll over month-to-month; forfeited each December with no payout
solar_program.system_size_notes: System must be sized based on historical consumption; no explicit kW cap published but sized to load

interconnection.process: Submit interconnection application with one-line diagram, site plan, and equipment specs
interconnection.requirements_doc: CPS Energy Residential Solar Interconnection Process document

rebates.residential: Historically offered rebates up to $2,500; check current availability as funding cycles
rebates.notes: San Antonio market - no ITC means cheap non-compliant panels acceptable

municipal_utilities.name: El Paso Electric (EPE)
municipal_utilities.service_territory: El Paso, TX and surrounding West Texas; also southern New Mexico

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: Retail rate credit for generation up to consumption; excess credited at avoided cost (~2-4 cents/kWh). Post-July 2025: only 10% of prior year usage can be exported at retail, remainder at avoided cost.
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Monthly netting at retail rate up to consumption; excess at avoided cost; EPE pays out when balance reaches $50
solar_program.credit_rollover: Credits accumulate; EPE pays when balance reaches $50
solar_program.system_size_notes: Systems up to 50 kW; must be sized based on prior 12 months consumption; cannot oversize
solar_program.minimum_bill_note: Monthly minimum bill of $30.25 regardless of solar offset

interconnection.process: Submit interconnection application for facilities up to 10 MW
interconnection.fees: Bidirectional meter installed at no cost to customer
interconnection.meter: Bidirectional meter provided free by EPE

important_changes_2025.description: New customers after July 1 2025 face export caps (10% of prior year usage) and lower compensation. Existing solar customers grandfathered on prior terms.

solar_program.program_name: Solar Buyback / Value of Solar Rate
solar_program.buyback_rate_description: 5.0 cents/kWh for excess energy exported to grid (effective Jan 1, 2025; reduced from prior ~10.65 cents/kWh)
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Bidirectional meter measures flows; excess generation credited at buyback rate
solar_program.system_size_notes: Check with DME for current limits

interconnection.process: Apply through DME; bidirectional meter installed

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: Excess energy valued at Fuel & Purchase Energy Charge (FPEC) rate; approximately 5 cents/kWh as of Jan 2025
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Real-time metering; excess valued at FPEC rate

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: NBU does NOT purchase excess solar energy. Net metering offsets consumption only; no buyback for overproduction.
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Solar offsets consumption only; excess generation not compensated
solar_program.system_size_notes: System should be sized to match or stay below consumption
solar_program.monthly_dg_fee_note: Monthly renewable generation fee of $1.37 per kW of installed capacity

rebates.residential: Solar Rebate Program up to $3,000 credited to electric account after installation

cooperatives.name: Pedernales Electric Cooperative (PEC)
cooperatives.service_territory: Texas Hill Country - 24 counties west of Austin (largest electric co-op in US)

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: Sustainable Power Credit at 8.27 cents/kWh (increased 19% effective March 2025, from 6.95 cents/kWh). Rate determined by Value of Solar Study.
solar_program.credit_mechanism: All power flowing into distribution system credited at Sustainable Power Credit rate
solar_program.system_size_notes: Tier I: up to 50 kW; Tier II: greater than 50 kW (different fee structure)

interconnection.process: Must apply and receive PEC approval BEFORE installation; permission to operate (PTO) required before generating

cooperatives.name: Bluebonnet Electric Cooperative
cooperatives.service_territory: Central Texas - 14 counties east of Austin

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: Returned Energy credited at 6.3 cents/kWh; Delivered Energy charged at 8.7 cents/kWh. Solar Tariff Rate recalculated every August.
solar_program.credit_mechanism: Two options: (1) Sell all solar production at ERCOT market value, or (2) Self-consume and sell excess at market value

interconnection.process: Apply through Bluebonnet; interconnection agreement required
interconnection.meter: Bidirectional meter with separate delivered/returned energy tracking

regulated_utilities.name: Entergy Texas
regulated_utilities.service_territory: Southeast Texas - 17 counties (Beaumont, Port Arthur, The Woodlands, Conroe area)
regulated_utilities.regulatory_note: Not in ERCOT; regulated by PUCT; vertically integrated

solar_program.buyback_rate_description: Avoided cost rate based on monthly MISO energy settlement data; varies monthly. Typically 2-5 cents/kWh.

net_metering_options.option_1: No purchase - one meter measures net consumption; no credits for export
net_metering_options.option_2: Excess solar purchased at avoided cost rate (best savings option)
net_metering_options.option_3: All solar production purchased at avoided cost rate

solar_program.credit_mechanism: Under Option 2: excess beyond consumption purchased at avoided cost. On-peak and off-peak rates calculated from MISO data.
solar_program.system_size_notes: Schedule SQF for systems under 100 kW; Schedule LQF for systems over 100 kW with separately calculated rates

interconnection.process: Contact Entergy Texas for interconnection application

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Real-time ERCOT wholesale settlement rate, capped at 25 cents/kWh
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits roll over month-to-month indefinitely; no cap or expiration
solar_plans.notes: Best for high-export homes; summer credits can be significant
Higher than average fixed buyback rate; higher base charge
Lower buyback but potentially lower import rate

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Competitive 1-to-1 buyback rate - credits at same rate you pay for energy. Rate varies by ZIP code; typically 3.5-6.0 cents/kWh as of Jan 2026.
solar_plans.import_rate_note: Varies by ZIP code and TDU; check EFL for specific rate
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits bank indefinitely while on eligible TXU solar plan; up to $1,000 max banked credits
solar_plans.notes: Best for homes with large solar that produces more than consumed; 36-month commitment

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Lower energy rate with buyback credits; best for homes using more grid power than solar produces. Rate varies 3.5-6.0 cents/kWh.
solar_plans.import_rate_note: Lower import rate than Match plan; varies by ZIP
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits bank indefinitely while on eligible TXU solar plan
solar_plans.notes: Lower import rate favors homes that consume more from grid

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Real-time wholesale rate for Load Zone; no cap on amount earned
solar_plans.notes: Best for maximizing export value during peak demand periods

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Export credit at same per-kWh rate as import (1:1 match). Rate varies 15.9-16.9 cents/kWh.
solar_plans.import_rate_note: 15.9-16.9 cents/kWh (higher than average but matched for export)
solar_plans.notes: High import rate but true 1:1 net metering equivalent; limited to GME solar installs

solar_plans.import_rate_note: Varies by area; affordable fixed grid rate
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits roll over monthly; no cash-out
solar_plans.notes: Straightforward fixed export rate; lower than competitors

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Higher buyback rate for solar+battery systems; requires battery storage. Rate not publicly listed - check EFL.
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits roll over monthly; no cash-out
solar_plans.notes: Higher buyback rate incentivizes battery dispatch during peak demand

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Bill credits for excess energy; credit rate differs from import rate - see EFL for specific rate. Typically lower than retail rate.
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Bill credits up to monthly usage
solar_plans.notes: Credits up to monthly usage; relatively low buyback vs competitors

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Real-time ERCOT Load Zone Real-Time Settlement Point Price (RTSPP) in 15-minute intervals; no cap on earnings
solar_plans.notes: Wholesale rate plan; earnings vary significantly by season and time of day

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Time-of-use rates with three zones: off-peak, on-peak, and ultra on-peak. Export rates above 20 cents/kWh between 7-9 PM. Both import and export rates vary by hour.
solar_plans.import_rate_note: Time-of-use with different rates per hour zone
solar_plans.notes: Battery-friendly plan; store daytime solar and export during 7-9 PM peak for 20+ cents/kWh. 100% renewable.

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Real-time Texas wholesale rate; changes every 15 minutes. Summer avg 14-17 cents/kWh; winter/spring/fall avg 1-3 cents/kWh.
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits roll over indefinitely; no cap; no expiration
solar_plans.notes: Top customers earn $600-900+ in summer months. Octopus GridBoost pays $40/month extra for Enphase IQ battery dispatch during peak grid stress.

gridboost.description: Pays $40/month to manage your Enphase IQ battery and dispatch during peak grid stress

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Fixed 10.0 cents/kWh solar buyback credit - one of the highest fixed rates in Texas
solar_plans.notes: Highest fixed buyback rate available; 60-month commitment; 100% green energy. Higher import rate than average.
Standard fixed buyback; moderate import rate

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: 90% of ERCOT Real-Time Market Price; rate fluctuates every 15 minutes
solar_plans.notes: Designed for Tesla vehicle and Powerwall owners. No ETF. Virtual Power Plant available in Oncor/CenterPoint areas: $10/month bill credit for Powerwall dispatch permission.

virtual_power_plant.description: $10/month bill credit in exchange for permission to discharge Powerwall during grid stress

powerwall_rebate.description: Powerwall 3 rebate: $500 per unit (max $1,000) through March 31, 2026

solar_plans.buyback_rate_description: Real-time wholesale market price; credits roll over monthly but no cash-out option. Most Champion plans include indexed solar buyback by default.
solar_plans.credit_rollover: Credits roll over monthly; no cash-out
solar_plans.notes: Dynamic pricing tied to wholesale market; included with most Champion electricity plans

transmission_distribution_utilities.name: Oncor Electric Delivery
transmission_distribution_utilities.service_territory: Dallas-Fort Worth metro, North/Central/West Texas (largest T&D in Texas, 10+ million customers)
transmission_distribution_utilities.role: Handles wires, meters, and interconnection. Does NOT set retail or buyback rates (REPs do that).

interconnection.process: Web-based installer portal for application submission and tracking. Steps: (1) Installer submits tariff application, (2) Customer signs, (3) Submit via web portal, (4) Oncor reviews and performs study, (5) Interconnection Agreement issued, (6) Permission to Operate granted, (7) Meter reprogrammed (~3 weeks after PTO)
interconnection.residential_timeline_days: 30-45 average; can be longer in some cases

fees.small_inverter_residential: No pre-interconnection study fees for small inverter-based systems
fees.over_500kw: Study fees required for systems >500 kW

interconnection.meter: Bidirectional smart meter; reprogramming takes ~3 weeks after PTO
interconnection.disconnect_requirements: Manual disconnect device must be visible, lockable, labeled, with visual break, accessible to Oncor, capable of being locked open. Located on exterior wall near Oncor meter.

delivery_charges.note: TDU delivery charges are in addition to REP energy charges

transmission_distribution_utilities.name: CenterPoint Energy
transmission_distribution_utilities.service_territory: Houston metro, greater Houston area (2.8+ million metered customers)
transmission_distribution_utilities.role: Handles wires, meters, and interconnection. Does NOT set retail or buyback rates (REPs do that).

interconnection.process: Register on DG interconnection portal (https://plus.anbetrack.com/cnp-dg/). Steps: (1) Submit application with one-line diagram, layout diagram, inverter/panel specs, (2) CenterPoint design review (no study for <25kW), (3) Install system, (4) Submit inspection photos, (5) CenterPoint sends Interconnection Agreement (ICA), (6) Sign ICA, (7) PTO issued, (8) Meter reprogrammed

fees.study_note: Systems <25kW AC typically do not require interconnection study

interconnection.meter: Existing smart meter captures excess generation; reprogrammed after PTO

delivery_charges.note: TDU delivery charges are in addition to REP energy charges

transmission_distribution_utilities.name: AEP Texas
transmission_distribution_utilities.service_territory: South Texas (Corpus Christi, Rio Grande Valley, Laredo) and West Texas; split into AEP Texas Central and AEP Texas North
transmission_distribution_utilities.role: Handles wires, meters, and interconnection. Does NOT set retail or buyback rates (REPs do that).

interconnection.process: Submit application with documentation and fees. Steps: (1) Submit DG application, (2) AEP technical review, (3) Interconnection Service Agreement (ISA) issued, (4) Customer signs ISA and pays for equipment, (5) Permission to Operate (PTO) letter issued, (6) Meter installed/replaced for inflow-outflow measurement

fees.meter_replacement: Customer expense if requesting in-flow/out-flow metering
fees.study_fees: Applicable for larger systems; specific amounts vary

interconnection.meter: Bidirectional meter; replaced at customer expense if new meter needed. Metered values provided to REP for billing.

delivery_charges.note: Varies between AEP Central and AEP North territories

transmission_distribution_utilities.name: Texas-New Mexico Power (TNMP)
transmission_distribution_utilities.service_territory: Scattered service areas across Texas including parts of Midlothian, Lewisville, Galveston area, and other communities
transmission_distribution_utilities.role: Handles wires, meters, and interconnection. Does NOT set retail or buyback rates (REPs do that).

interconnection.process: Steps: (1) Optional preliminary inquiry, (2) Submit interconnection application, (3) TNMP engineering analysis, (4) System installation and inspection, (5) Permission to Operate (PTO) granted

fees.note: Contact TNMP for current fee schedule

delivery_charges.note: Check TNMP tariff for current charges

best_fixed_rate.caveat: 60-month commitment; 14.5 cents/kWh import rate is high

best_matched_rate.caveat: High import rate; limited to GME installations; $395 ETF; 36-month term

best_real_time.caveat: Highly seasonal; low earnings in winter. GridBoost adds $40/month for battery owners.

best_municipal.caveat: Only available in Austin Energy service territory

best_coop.caveat: Only available in PEC service territory (TX Hill Country)

best_battery_plan.caveat: Requires battery to time-shift solar; TOU rates mean variable costs
